Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2010 07:54PM MsBliss wrote: Well, what do you expect from an organization, Komen, that is part of Pink, Inc?  Their latest pink marketing campaign is with Kentucky Fried Chicken!  Yes, got cancer?  Here's how you do your part:  add some deep fried, factory farmed chicken to your diet, along with some acrylamides, but don't worry about the food as long as you are involved with Pink, Inc..... Don't be disappointed by these things....these organizations are not here to really help--they are here to self propagate and increase their budgets. As far as your wife is concerned, welcome to the insanity.  It is true, an illegal alien has better access to unencumbered health care than a working insured person, or a legal resident.  We have truly lost our way. Now, here is what you do:  you make a stink, with the hospital, with the press office, anyway you can.  There is no way that she should be forced to wait to remove that tumor.  No way.  Write letters to the hospital admin, fax them, call them.  Get the noise going.  It is a nasty fight, but I bet you will prevail.
Posts.Title: Looks Like I'll Have To Take My Wife Out Of The Country Sepahunt22 CathyB

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 11:34PM - edited Jul 18, 2010 11:56PM by MsBliss Your description does sound like a melanoma.  I have a sister who had it and a friend who had it.  After excision and pathology study for good margins, THEY ARE FINE.  This is easily resectable but not to be taken casually.  Get her to the doctor you have scheduled for tomorrow....don't worry about scheduling a dematologist yet.  The Gyn should bump her priority up to a specialist derm if that is needed.  This growth needs to come off immediately.  Let us know how it goes tomorrow.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 11:41PM MsBliss wrote: I should add that she will need to see a dermatologist/surgical dermatologist, but it may be easier to get her in quicker once you establish the urgency with the doctor you have scheduled for tomorrow morning.  If the doctor tomorrow does not get your daughter in to see a specialist immediately, then call and get her in ASAP, even if it means you have to wait inbetween patients for an opening.

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 01:14AM - edited Jul 19, 2010 01:27AM by MsBliss I just re-read your post.  I don't see any mention of brown pigment.  Is there any mole/freckle coloring or is it all "bruisey" looking?  If it is all bruisey multi colored then I mispoke about the situation.  It could be an infected cyst, a bug bite, even a thrombosed artery or capillary.  After re-reading your post, I feel that the melanoma issue is not too likely.

Posts.Content: MsBliss wrote: Apparently the surgical pathology on the removed tumor was limited to the study of the margins and no further biology was done other than what was done for the biopsy report (which was done by a different lab).  I am flummoxed by this as my tumor may be true medullary, but that very restricted classification is not permitted until studies are done on the whole removed tumor.  But no microscopic studies on the border of the entire tumor have been done on the removed tumor specimen.  Without this info, I cannot satisfy the final criteria for true medullary bc.  This would make a world of difference to me because if it turns out to be true medullary, not medullary features, then I will have the option of not needing chemo or radiation.  Is it standard op procedure to not do biology on the actual tumor other than for receptors? Dx 3/09 Triple negative, stg1, SNB0/2, BRCA neg, CHEK 2 pos, 1.4cm plus 7mm DCIS, ki67 70-90%, lumpectomy w/re-excision, no chemo/no rads due to delays from secondary health issues; evidence based interventions. Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2010 04:07PM MsBliss wrote: Dear IMC1970--if the doctor never checked your lymph nodes during the primary in 2006, then why did they tell you that you were stage 1?   Was it because the tumor was small?  Even a small tumor can have positive nodes....and with tnbc, it is of course, more important to make certain what your lymph node status is.  I don't  understand why they didn't check your nodes.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 11:29AM MsBliss wrote: Thank you PJ for posting this link.  It is an education.  Information is power, especially with this type of thing. This article is on top of the disclosure that several major hospitals in major medical centers have been overdosing patients getting brain CT scans.  8 times the dose because of software and calibration issues.  What else has been going on under the radar?  I had a "peculiar" PET scan experience at UC Irvine many years ago--they were "unhappy" with the isotope that came up for my test and "cooked" up another dose which was then used on me for the test.  I wonder if that could have possibly caused or contributed to my currrent cancer. As the article said, there is no reporting requirement in the industry.  What kind of b*llsh*t is that????
Posts.Title: Frightening NYT article on radiation TX pj12 MAGOB

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 09:51AM MsBliss wrote: I understand your devastation.....I was talked up on the ns bmx because I had triple negative and high grade DCIS.  I had IDC, a particularly bad one, but stage 1.  I did lumpectomy, and re excision and had to skip chemo and rads because of secondary health issues.  Then I got the lecture from two bc sisters that getting the breasts off was the best way to go for long term peace of mind.  One had already done a prophylactic bmx with recon and looked incredible, the other, the same, but with poor results and complications much like yours.  I went to see a plastic surgeon who was pushing me very hard to do the bmx with recon.  He sent me to a breast cancer surgeon with whom he does the recon with, and she said yes but---wait.  Yes, it is a great surgery, yes, you will look fantastic, but no, it is fraught with complications and you must think it through.  I did not end up having the bmx, but I think you were talked up as I was; bc is a frightening prospect and we make decisions in the interest of preserving our health.   Now, you need to sort out your infections and give your tissues time to heal.    From what you wrote, it appears you are more upset about living with the aftermath, not just getting through the infection, which will ultimately resolve. You need to get good nutrition to help this process--it will make a difference. But what do you do after the infection and inflammation is gone?  What are you left with? After the tissues are completely healed, you need to research microfat grafting.  There is a thread here at BCO which is all about microfat grafting.  I have not had it done, I have no experience with the doctors who do it, and I have no deep knowledge of the procedures involved.  BUT, I did read and see enough about it to know you may be able to benefit from it, also that it is a multi stage process.  There is a doctor in Florida, Dr Khouri, who has a lot of experience with it.  I think this might be able to restore your feelings of "wholeness".  The photos I have seen are miraculous. All my best, MsBliss
Posts.Title: Help-complications force me to join this "club" jtslg lollypop59

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 05:58PM MsBliss wrote: I had several pathology reports done because they kept name dropping "medullary features" in my reports.  I needed to know exactly what it meant.  I had an interest in settling the meaning because I could not do chemo due to secondary health issues and I needed to know the cold hard facts. What I learned is that "true medullary"(TMC)  is very rare.  "Atypical medullary" (AMC) is a little less rare.  Here is the difference:  under the Ridolfi guidelines, TMC needs to have 5 features.  If it has all 5 than your prognosis is very favorable.  In fact, if you are early stage 1, you can possibly stop treatment after surgery--no chemo, no rads.  It looks like an aggressive cell, but the tumor behaves well and doesn't tend to metasticize.  Now, if you have AMC, and have two of the features of "synctial growth pattern" in at least 2/3 of the tumor and a dense lymphocytic envelope and some prominent lymph infiltrate, then you have a favorable turn as well, BUT NO PATHOLOGIST OR ONC WILL ACKNOWLEDGE THIS ANYMORE, because they fear you will undertreat.  So they treat AMC, even with those premium features, like IDC.  But a large study in Denmark disagrees with this tactic.  If you have one or some of the other med features like "pushing borders" or a mild lymph infiltrate, then you really will not benefit from any favorable interpretation, and should def treat it as IDC. You need to find out exactly what kind of medullary features you had....which ones?  If you had a dense lymphoplasmatic response, that is significant.  Did you?
Posts.Title: Medullary Features and Medullary Carcinoma angelcakes MsBliss

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 01:37PM MsBliss wrote: Bennymuffins, I had a seroma after breast surgery for a benign mass....it was so easy and painless to drain because it wants to open up and do that.  It felt a lot better and healed quickly after it was allowed to drain over a few days.  If it comes to this, don't be too fearful of lancing it--in my experience, it was well worth it.
